both cushioned shoes and office chairs are really bad for you. just like using the smith machine in a gym to do squats/bench press. you ingrain bad patterns of motion. it harms you, more than helps.

cushioning and support should always be taken care of by your own muscles, not by external crutches.

when you wear cushioned shoes, your calves and ankles do not do the work they're supposed to do to cushion you from impact. the shoes might feel comfy, but they make your muscles lazy. your body forgets how to absorb impact on its own. over time, that weakness leads to problems because you tend to develop bad running patterns, which you wouldn't if you were running barefoot.

likewise, when you use an office chair, you are not using your back muscles to support you. use them long enough and your spine loses its natural strength and alignment. you suffer from chronic pain and stiffness.

the same goes for using the smith machine: no stabiliser muscle engagement, bad range and pattern of motion. they're training wheels for lifters. your stabilizers never learn to do their job, your form never develops, and you're an accident waiting to happen.

these are all crutches. anyone who tells you otherwise is insincere and never studied their own body. our bodies are designed to support themselves. every time you outsource that role to an external crutch, you trade short-term ease for long-term dysfunction.

"If I speak in the spirit of this time,' I must say: no one and nothing can justify what I must proclaim to you. Justification is superfluous to me, since I have no choice, but I must. I have learned that in addition to the spirit of this time there is still another spirit at work, namely that which rules the depths of everything contemporary.

The spirit of this time would like to hear of use and value. I also thought this way, and my humanity still thinks this way. But that other spirit forces me nevertheless to speak, beyond justification, use, and meaning. Filled with human pride and blinded by the presumptuous spirit of the times, I long sought to hold that other spirit away from me. But I did not consider that the spirit of the depths from time immemorial and for all the future possesses a greater power than the spirit of this time, who changes with the generations. The spirit of the depths has subjugated all pride and arrogance to the power of judgment. He took away my belief in science, he robbed me of the joy of explaining and ordering things, and he let devotion to the ideals of this time die out in me.
He forced me down to the last and simplest things.

The spirit of the depths took my understanding and all my knowledge and placed them at the service of the inexplicable and the paradoxical.

He robbed me of speech and writing for everything that was not in his service, namely the melting together of sense and nonsense, which produces the supreme meaning."

came across this term "eightfold fence" in shogun. if you google the phrase, you get lots of different interpretations of the term. many interpret it as a coping mechanism.

bhai, it is not a coping mechanism. it alludes to awareness and the aloneness of the observer. no matter what happens, everything ultimately happens in awareness. awareness is the only still and unchanging reality, and in that sense, it doesn't interact with the world and its things at all. it is itself all worlds and all things, so it is indifferent to whatever happens within them.

the eightfold fence actually talks about resting in pure and indifferent awareness. it's not a coping mechanism but an iykyk thing.

"Do you know "The Eightfold Fence"? From the time we are small, it is something we are taught to build within ourselves. An... impenetrable wall, behind which we can retreat whenever we need. You must train yourself to listen without hearing. For instance, you can listen to the sound of a blossom falling or the rocks growing. If you really listen, your present circumstance vanishes. Do not be fooled by our politeness. Our bows, our maze of rituals. Beneath it all... we could be a great distance away. Safe. And alone."

master krishnamurti talked about this listening and aloneness throughout his life, that too in pretty much the same words. it's a nondual teaching, not some silly "compartmentalization"

take some time out just to close all the random unfinished loops hogging space in the background. 

like the browser gets sluggish with too many opened and unread tabs, the brain does too. unfinished tasks, nagging worries, half-baked ideas ‚Äî all steal focus and energy.

the only hack to have to clean less is to clean more often. regular housekeeping. a few minutes each day to close some tabs. make a decision, take an action, tie up a loose end. bit by bit, reclaim headspace.

keeps the cruft manageable. 

the same applies across life. dishes, laundry, clutter. stay on top of it a little at a time. daily sweeps prevent the need for giant purges later.

solve the most immediate problem as soon as you encounter it. soon, you won't have many problems.

flow states are an outcome of a flow process.

if you have to teach it, is it capable of learning outside the methods you taught it?

when you train a model to play super mario, you're pre-programming it with certain axiomatic rules that decide the direction it optimises in. you penalise it for engaging in behaviours that lead to death and you reward it for engaging in behaviours that lead to making progress in the game. so although it can get good at the game after a lot of trial and error, and guided by the pre-programmed reward structure, it has no awareness of the intent being programmed into itself.

on the other hand, it's very easy to have a scenario with a child where the child, instead of optimizing for clearing levels, figures out that it enjoys mario dying in funny ways. so the child decides her own intent and then goes after achieving that. she decides her own reward structure. there is awareness and flexibility at the very level of intent.

the model only learns what you tell it to learn, and in ways you train it to learn.

a child learns what she wants to learn, and then also decides how she wants to learn it. she comes up with her own techniques and methods.

imagine you wake up in a totally strange world. everything you know is suddenly useless. 

what do you do?

first, you look for anything familiar. something to build on. at the same time, you start guessing and trying things out. you do stuff and see what happens. that's how you figure out the rules and ideas of this new place.

it's like when a kid plays a new video game, like portal. the game has its own weird rules, concepts, and physics. so she just tries things and sees what works. in half an hour, she's got a basic idea of how portal works in her head. and she keeps updating it as new concepts and ideas are introduced at every level.

can a big language model do that today? can it jump into a new game, figure out the rules, and beat it right away?

for an llm to demonstrate this kind of intelligence, it would need to go beyond pattern matching and knowledge retrieval. it would need to be able to:

- identify when its existing knowledge is insufficient or inapplicable to a new context

- conjecture. generate novel hypotheses or strategies for navigating the unfamiliar situation

- test these hypotheses through experimentation and learn from the results

- rapidly construct a coherent mental model of the new domain, including its entities, rules, and dynamics

- apply this model to make accurate predictions, solve problems, and achieve goals within the new context

- continuously update and refine the model based on new observations and experiences

if it can, then it's intelligent. if it can't, then maybe it's not as smart as we think.

"i see you all are paying a lot of attention to this opinion, so the only way i can earn your attention is by telling you how wrong you are."

a good argument never needs to diss an existing argument to make a point. but you need that contrast for marketing purposes, and hence what you get is a fully polarized discourse that pits one against another.

no human being is even remotely as extreme in person as you will find them to be on social media.

good thinking is more than capable of standing its ground without having to resort to ad-hominem comparisons.

at an even more fundamental level, our reasoning about things is utterly reflexive and hinges on referents. we rarely reason using first principles. this results in perpetual oscillation from one extreme to the other.

the correct opinion that maps reality faithfully rarely is "the opposite of an existing opinion."

cliches feel profound when you arrive at them via an experience you couldn't have conceptualised.

you can memorize the proverb, but you can't see yourself falling into the very traps that the proverb warns against, till you fall into them. and then they are imbued with a totally new life. you can see the profundity.

most cliches are very surprising when you really get them. for example, i still have no visceral sense for compounding, iteration, practice, or experimentation. 

i don't recall having conducted a proper controlled scientific experiment even once in my life.

in the things i got good at, i never saw the progress as "compounding" or "iterating". in the things i got good at, i never saw "progress". but i progressed.

but we throw these cliches around like we understand them. we do not.

here are ten cliches i can bet money on that you don't understand or live by, even when you claim that you do:

Honesty is the best policy.
Actions speak louder than words.
Better late than never.

Time heals all wounds.

good editing is honest and intimate with intent. and we have no clarity of intent. 

editing is hard because clarity of intent is hard.

the question i'm more interested in is: 

if you have distribution via a platform and a business wants to advertise on your platform to benefit from that distribution, is it the business's responsibility or your responsibility to make the ad work?

if it's your responsibility and you don't do a good job at it, you won't get ad revenue, but you will not lose distribution *because* of that. rather, you will not be able to keep the platform alive, in which case, all three parties ‚Äî the business, the platform, and the user ‚Äî lose.

but if the business considers it its own responsibility to create ads that people don't look away from and squeeze the distribution on offer to its fullest, they now support the platform while improving their ads and entertaining their customers.

former is lose-lose-lose
latter is win-win-win

i was a chronic nail biter all through my childhood. you'd never see me with a nail cutter. i even trimmed all my toe nails with my teeth.(yes, i am bendy that way.)

do you know how i stopped doing it?

one day i was biting my fingernails, as usual. and i caught myself doing that in a mirror i was sitting next to, on my left. i realised how stupid i looked doing it.

and i never did it again.

moral of the story:

i wasn't shamed into quitting. in fact, i'd never even entertained the idea of giving it up. the habit seemed way too innocuous for me to give it up.

i quit because there was this single moment of clarity ‚Äî one reason for not biting my nails that really CLICKED WITH ME.

you cannot manufacture that moment. you don't know what it looks like for you. but when it comes, dropping the habit becomes as simple as breathing.

shame doesn't do the job. you need to discover the reason that clicks for you. and there's no process for this. any process only builds up a dam that either eventually breaks in the same river or silently spills into other rivers.

the underlying principle here is:

purely transactional and transparent relationships are the best ones. the moment both parties sign up for "free" stuff, they also sign up to pay hidden costs. this is okay with friends and family ‚Äî we call it trust. and even that comes with its fair share of surprise, disappointment and resentment.

but with strangers at scale, it will always lead to acrimony. it's only a matter of time.

a good way to bypass information asymmetry while negotiating is to decide the price you would be willing to pay for the product, regardless of its market price and then anchor all negotiation around that price.

the jtbd is not competing with the seller; it is leaving with something that feels like a great return for the money you're shelling out.

i personally do not enter someone else's playground and try to compete with them. my default stance during these situations is ‚Äî everyone here is smarter than me, knows a lot more than me, so let's not try to be a smartass just for the sake of an ego boost. 

i will lead with the price i think is right for the product. if it's cheaper than that, i'll maybe do a round of negotiation as a formality to see if i can bring the price down even further. if not, i'll still buy it.

if the price is higher than what i think the product justifies, i will try to bring it closer to what i'm willing to pay for it. if i can't, i won't buy it.

as much as i love master j. krishnamurti and the impact he's had on my life, i am quite aware of the problem with his style.

for the average person who doesn't really know what self-reflection looks like, it's hard to apply his teachings to their own unique situation.

i think that for this kind of teaching to really help someone, it has to be super personal and avoid generalities. it has to show what true honesty looks like. if i wanted to help someone understand, i'd have to reveal my own thoughts in such detail that it would be like pouring my heart out for everyone to see. 

but krishnamurti did the opposite. he never got into specifics.

i get why he did that. he didn't want to reveal anything that would get templatized into a method. so he stuck to general truths. 

exploring self-reflection as it happens, in a specific situation and in real-time, would make someone incredibly vulnerable. they might face instant judgment and "cancellation" from others. there's just so much going on behind why you choose what you choose, and usually, it's backed by an intent you wouldn't feel comfortable to reveal.

but at the same time, i think there's a lot of value in doing this if the goal is to help someone really understand what the real deal looks like. sure, people might try to copy it, but the more details you give, the more someone can grasp how deep the identity rabbit hole goes.

it's like if a good therapist decided to publish conversations with their patients anonymously, just to show the world the kind of attention and honesty it takes to get to the truth.

this is also why they tell you that arriving at the truth is almost impossible without establishing a deep and personal connection with a master. the generalities offered in books will never apply to your own unique conditioning and struggles.

have always advised people to run and workout with shoes that do not have a heel, if not barefoot. no one listens. everyone wants the expensive asics and nikes to signal wealth and seriousness, wealth more than seriousness.

it takes just 3 months to fix a collapsed ankle. it's a learned pattern of walking you have to unlearn and replace with a better pattern. yes, for 3 months, you'll have to pay attention to how you walk and fix your feet whenever you find your ankles collapsing inwards. but that's all you need to do.

you will avoid a lot of knee and hip problems down the line.

1. everything is better done barefoot.

2. most people start running without ever learning how to run (yes, running for a long period without developing injuries is a skill you need to learn, just as important as learning how to deadlift or squat with proper form)

3. watch how milind soman runs and watch how your average normie runs. big difference. the latter is only building up to an injury.
all this is wisdom you can easily accumulate if you were more observant of your own body. no referent is necessary.

was fortunate to workout at a gym that didn't mandate footwear. worked out barefoot and also corrected a chronic collapsed ankle problem developed in childhood. just fixing that issue fixes so many problems downstream.

every other person you'll see walking has a collapsed ankle/flat foot. people compensate by wearing cushioned shoes. it aggravates the problem. their ankle and hip mobility is atrocious. can't even do a proper atg squat.

the only solution is to strengthen your arch and walk on the balls of your feet, not on your heels.

when a master points out your excuses, it is not an indictment of your unseriousness or sincerity or your worth as a human. rather, it is a plea to discover why they exist and where your true desires lie, for an excuse can only ever cloak a false desire. with genuine desires, a mere admission of reality as it is suffices, because of the binary nature of the search. 

in other words, if you ever wanted something truly, why would you ever try to weasel away from the fact that you do not have it yet with some shabby excuse? it would solve nothing for you. you either have it or you don't. and nothing else would suffice in its place. it is genuine because *you* want it, not because the world wants you to have it. so there's no point in fooling others and making them think you have it. you cannot fool yourself.

the biggest give away of a shabby snake oil salesman is not that he wants to show the world he has it, but that he's trying to convince himself that he does.

the desperation for validation is a giveaway, not the ostentation. many confuse ostentation for charlatanism, but it is the wrong level at which you should judge anyone.

the correct level will always be their alignment, coherence, and composure.

composure doesn't mean being an inert pacifist. when krishna urged arjuna to go to war, he had composure. when you try to put blinders on yourself due to your attachments, pride, and affiliations, you lose composure.

a monk who doesn't fight because he has sworn to remain peaceful lacks composure. and a warrior who can't enjoy peace because he only feels validated when at war also lacks composure.

someone who truly wanted to win will have no qualms living with the fact that they lost.

yes, it was a good game.
yes, you learned.
yes, you earned the respect of your competitor and the audience.

does it matter?

not at all.

you lost. and that's about it.

and if everything is material, real, including your thoughts (the fact that you're thinking and feeling is undeniable) then why don't you act on them?

it is this that needs to be studied; whether the world is illusion or material doesn't matter. what matters is your misalignment with either of those stances. it is the misalignment that's the problem, not the underlying axiom.

with wired charging, the act of charging is a distinct event: you plug in your device and then wait for it to charge.

wireless charging, otoh, turns it into more of an ambient, ever-present background process. you don't have to actively initiate or monitor it ‚Äî provided you are at your desk and your phone stays docked in the wireless charging station or pad.

now, the charging happens automatically without you having to think about it or take action.

so even though wireless charging is slow (the usual complaint), the behaviour it promotes ensures that your phone is always more or less charged, and you're on average less conscious about battery level.

they are not movie-brained people frantically oscillating between fairyland and disappointing reality. they don't live in the past or in an imaginary future.

the mind is like a thief. if you catch the thief in the act, it stops tricking you on that level after some time. it now sees that the trick doesn't seem to be working on you anymore.

so it comes up with a subtler, more advanced level of treachery. once you see that too, it tries to get even subtler. you can literally see it going both horizontal and vertical, trying to latch on to any and all desires that may be still latent within you. because it wants to survive.

every layer of treachery you discover unlocks new self-knowledge. you may now know a new kind of insecurity you've always harbored but never knew it existed before this event.

and so, you unravel increasingly subtler layers of your psyche, and the images that make it up.

the only way beyond the mind is by understanding the mind and how it works. and you will develop a newfound respect for just the sheer gravity of the situation and the scale at which the mind is operating at. this comes as a huge shock the first time you see it.

the mind is nothing short of godly. it is brahma itself ‚Äî with devices and deception far subtler than you can perceive.

it is a subject where you will never run out of material or learning. you're always at the beginning of infinity.

the only way to understand what i'm saying is to see the whole process of movie-making happen in the mind, while it is happening, in real time.

you will also need to see how the images are interfering with how you think about things and make decisions, in real time.

then, and only then, will you see the kind of scam you're pulling on yourself and romanticising it while you're at it.

once you see the emptiness within things, the suffering inherent to desire becomes salient. you see this suffering not just within yourself but within others, too. and it brings me to tears, especially when i see it in my mother, or even young kids desiring fancy stuff they've seen others have on social media. it breaks my heart.

i used to desire a lot as a child. my mind was flush with wants. and given my obsessive nature, i used to sit for long periods in the day with my eyes closed trying to imagine what i wanted in all its vibrant detail.

i envied a lot. i hankered a lot. didn't have any money to get what i wanted. and then i started earning. stsrted buying stuff i always wanted.

but nothing sufficed. every time a desire was fulfilled, i already had two waiting in queue.

then, i started to question how i was generating all these desires. found out most of them came from the culture.

and the more i caught myself in the act of borrowing a desire, the fewer desires i borrowed.

most popular desires you have come from movies. without movies, you'd have no reference to conjure up meaning and aesthetic around the desire. you're not that creative. and you reason by reference. if you had no cultural references, you'd immediately cut down your desires by a huge percentage. like 95% +

here's the problem i usually run into:

evo psych/bio explanations that talk about humans "in general" allow the individual to shrewdly project their own reasons onto everyone in order to dilute the moral shame associated with what they secretly intend to do.

there's a strong reason behind the behavior that they're trying to mask with an excuse, because stating it bluntly would make them sound afraid/immoral.

so the first step is to make the person say it like it is, without embellishments or references to authority, so that they can overcome the social guilt/shame associated with the fact. only then they can think clearly about the situation.

being stuck in reasoning by generalities/references to other people and what they do never allows the individual to see the truth of their own situation in all its acuity.

all excuses secretly or blatantly hint at reasons - that's not the problem. the problem is the frame of such excuses misrepresents/obscures the real reason. and acknowledging the honest reason would be actually useful. my attempt is always to make the person arrive at the real reason in its most blunt and honest framing versus resorting to some feel-good excuse that saves the person from articulating a not-so-appetizing reason.

an example of something quite useful i learned from photography that carried over to my writing:

pay attention to the edges of your photograph. keep them clean, or they will lead the viewer's eyes away from the subject to something irrelevant poking out of the edge.

the analogy carries over to writing quite well:

if you wish your reader to stay with you all throughout your essay and understand your central argument well, refrain from introducing associations that may lead them on unrelated tangents.

it's the difference between an essay that's tight and nails the argument, versus an essay that sounds like an incoherent ramble.

been a while since i started learning photography. and i now understand writing so much better because of it.

when you start as a total beginner in something new, it not only helps you relate to your primary craft but also helps you understand how beginners in your field feel.

because if you're naturally talented at something, you instinctively skip over some levels of abstraction. but others might not have that same instinct. to really help them get better, you need to think like a beginner. 

but it's hard to do that for something you just get intuitively!

the trick i'm discovering is to pick up an adjacent skill as a newbie ‚Äî preferably a skill you have no natural talent for. this lets you relate to the people you're coaching, since you'll know firsthand what learning is like.

in writing, there are words. and there are sentences you create with those words. and then there are stories you weave with those sentences. and then there's the meta-skill of identifying what makes a good story.

same deal with photography ‚Äì the words are the rules for what makes a great frame, the sentences are the process of capturing those frames in a way that's interesting, and the photo book is the story you tell by putting all those photos together.

with photography, i started with words. i'm only now starting to write some decent sentences. and i'm still far away from telling stories using static visuals.

but the whole process is helping me appreciate the struggles beginners go through: their tendency to fall for simplistic prescriptions, and to follow rules without developing any understanding or eye for the craft. 

ultimately, it's helping me be a better writer/teacher.

best not dunk on someone's personality w/o any understanding of their objectives or intent.

critiquing personality is only useful when you understand someone's objectives and know that their personality will not help them achieve those objectives.

for example, you may critique a nerd's personality when they're trying to win the dating game in a dating pool of non-nerds. or you may critique a reclused 10x IC's personality when their objective is to improve their optics within the org.

you should be more social! you should dress better! you should not be arrogant!

objectives demand trade-offs. but most critique assumes objectives when it has no right to.

@tsawrub any borrowed idea that gets internslised as raw intuition is as good as a self-developed one. the difference is between owning vs. borrowing. intuition is always owned. rationality is usually externalised by citing facts and data.

show me a kid who wants to be an MBA when they grow up. kids don't think in vague abstractions. they think in clear actions like driving a truck, or flying a plane, or building a rocket, or making youtube videos, or being a guitarist, etc.

an MBA is not a thing you do. it's not concrete enough. hence, the people who do it also completely rely on external models without having built any concrete intuition of their own.

the medium is the message.

for example, "more money" is not a great goal if you wish to develop any craft. because it is so far removed from the process (there are ten thousand ways to make more money), that it only betrays a lack of clarity.

i can psychoanalyse this further by citing the reason most people choose to do an MBA in the first place. an MBA is what you do when either you have no clarity about the goal or your goal is so far removed from the process, it's good as having no goal.

MBAs who tend to rely on facts and data have no personal intuition about the product. they're top-down, TAM-driven thinkers. this is great if you wish to build something mid in a large market, but it's terrible if you wish for the product to exhibit any strong personality or craft.

the divide isn't between rationalism and intuition, it is between what's earned and what's borrowed. intuition is always earned, but facts and data are usually borrowed. it isn't about rationalism as much as it is about borrowed models vs. self-developed ones.

it's the difference between having a discrete understanding of reality vs. an integral one.

quantize enough and everything is rational in the limit. that's a meaningless argument. the distinction is about what people intend to convey when they use the distinction, not about definitions.

so what happens when you ask chatgpt to first learn paulg's voice and then replicate it on this new idea?

- it makes a statistical mapping of the training data on a bazillion dimensions, like a markov chain. and then it arrives at a weight for tokens in paulg's memeplex.
- as long as you ask it to output content on ideas, relations, and associations paulg has already made in his writing, it delivers well.
- but surprise! paulg has never written about entertainment and outcomes. oops!
- so when it comes across "entertainment", it dives into the entertainment memeplex and arrives at the likeliest chain of tokens as output, given the entertainment memeplex.
- while doing so, it also completely loses track of paulg's style of writing and delivers what it considers most similar to the language inder the "entertainment" category of associations.

one of the many reasons why i respect paulg:

ask claude opus to impersonate his style of writing. it can't. at least not with few-shot prompting. and opus is the best model for creative writing we have so far.

writers who have high semantic and propositional density will be hard to replace. and the more fundamental layer here is the raw ability to arrive at insightful conjectures via a simple, logical chain of reasoning.

semantic density = amount of meaning or information conveyed per sentence. when a text has high semantic density, each sentence carries substantial weight and earns its place in the text.

propositional density = number of distinct propositions or ideas expressed in a text relative to the number of words or sentences used. when you write with high propositional density, a higher proportion of sentences contain a distinct, idea/observation/insight that builds upon the central argument.

quality writing takes work. and conflating convoluted-ness with quality is an error.

i'm not saying that all writing needs to be simple and have short sentences. some logical arguments/chains of thought will require compound sentences that take up a whole paragraph. anyone who has read good philosophy knows this.

but most people can improve their writing by just improving their sentence structure.

you're most risk averse in things you don't understand well. HRs do not understand hiring well. only good hiring managers do. and they will be able to make bets and take risks an HR never will. if you want apprenticeships and high-res signals, first get rid of clueless HRs.

because an HR is solving for downside risk, not upside.

hiring is the hardest problem in a startup. you're trying to convince the most disagreeable and smart people to come work with you. your success depends on them.

hence, startup folks naturally tend to develop a bias against pedigree over time. for the kind of people they're looking for, pedigree isn't a high-res or accurate signal. but the world isn't just startups. and not everyone has an eye for latent potential outside of pedigree. very few have.
biggest mistake scale-afficianados make is thinking every skillset is easily transferable.
goodhart never stays out of the picture. that idiot always rushes into every frame, as soon as you have a frame.

you can fight against pedigree all you want; i have too ‚Äî only to finally realise that i myself use cognitively efficient signals all the time while making judgments about stuff i'm not an expert in.

you cannot fight human nature. you cannot ask your average recruiter to evaluate every candidate independently, via a mechanism that takes 20x more effort if not more. your average HR is not a craftsperson. they do not know what craftt looks like. they can't optimize for it.

that's a whole, extremely valuable business in itself, that only a craftsperson can pull off. take @_svs_ for example. it's a niche business and he will be able to command a good premium for it - partly because he himself has pedigree and credentials to make a case for himself and his eye for craft.

you can't expect it from your average recruiter. hence, we have degrees, follower counts, production quality, etc. as cognitively efficient metrics to base our judgments on.

to say otherwise would only be hypocritical, considering we all indulge in the same.

need x risk is a great frame.

costly signals are needed both ways. a tier-1 degree is currently the best abstraction we have at scale for all 3 stakeholders: student, institution, recruiter

the way i see it, any change in the system will be pushed by the recruiters.

recruiter preference influences student influences institute/pedagogy/delivery

apprenticeship is useless when recruiter doesn't see its value. and it will objectively be useless when everyone gets into it to make a quick buck.

costly signals exist for a reason. apprenticeships have been costly conventionally because it's damn hard for someone legitimate to accept you as an intern. and this is where they derive most of their signalling value from.

internships are definitely better from a study pov, but finally, the market seeks cognitively efficient signals for proficiency, leading to the same pedigree problem.

the midwits will tell you that being extreme in your takes is not wise, but the wise know that sometimes an extreme stance is essential to achieve the intended effect.

being intentionally extreme isn't about emotion, although it may look like that. it is about prioritisation and forcing clarity in a situation, where the 5% is holding you back from moving on the 95%.

zen employs this technique quite well. a master tells you to do something without revealing the logic behind it.

nuance would prescribe explaining the logic to the student for the learning to accrue.

but the master knows that trying to explain the logic would only create friction and confusion within the student instead of helping him. whereas simply doing the thing would help him understand the thing a lot faster.

moral of the story:

all prescriptions are unwise, including this one. what matters is not the act but the intention behind it. an intentional extremism can often be instrumental in furthering the cause.

you don't use precision while stating probabilities because precise statements also unlock demand for precise reasoning behind those statements.

if i said something is "70% likely" instead of "probably", readers would be more prone to ask how I arrived at that number, while they would let the latter pass. and the likelihood of asking for the underlying reasoning gets higher the more precise the number gets.

consider 70% vs. 72% vs. 73.4%

you may not enquire at 70% but you will definitely enquire at 73.4%

"73.4%? hmm, that sounds oddly specific. wonder how you arrived at that number?"

if you wish to hedge, hedge casually. or you activate the rationalist within others.

of course, hedging isn't a free pass and comes with 'how seriously others take you' as a trade-off. but how much attention people pay to you also depends on how interesting and novel your conjectures are. the more novel a conjecture, the more you're allowed to hedge; for readers, the novelty of a pattern and what it unlocks can obviate the demand to be precise.

caution: the frame i'm using to think about this is persuasiveness, not accuracy. if you wish to understand something for yourself and are betting money based on that understanding, always use hard numbers.

i personally know people who are stuck in the past and refuse to come out of it. they approach every new development cynically and can be insufferable in their allegiance to the ways of the past. and everyone is conditioned to the past in their own way ‚Äî some subtle, some not so subtle.

bryan is one of a kind. in that he has managed to retain the curiosity, optimism, and fun of a child while approaching his 50s. how many others are like him? most humans around you are so conditioned by the time they reach 20, let alone 50, it's hard to rescue them from that kind of blindness.

@NihiruuNeko it's an iteration in the sense evolution is. not in the planned sense humans iterate in. and the former is way more antifragile than the latter, which is mostly reductive, silly, and not good outside of the most constrained environments.

for instance, we have gen-z and gen-z-isms because we needed a generation who can quickly adapt to a technological world.

now consider the disdain boomers have for gen-z and what it reflects about the mind in general: it hates change and loves being set in its ways. and gen-z will be no different when they grow older.

now imagine a world full of curmudgeonly boomers who never die. it's systemic fragility.

and if the counter-argument is that eradicating human death will keep the slate clean all the time ‚Äî i don't think so.

solving for human transcience doesn't solve for natural transcience. the ego has a tendency to accumulate and become rigid and inflexible,regardless of its attachment to other humans. that's senescence.

and death is an evolutionary mechanism against developing fragility at the level of the species.
death is an iteration; it's a chance to pivot with a clean slate. you can adapt and evolve instead of becoming increasingly rigid and fragile over the course of your life, as you usually do.

okay, let's consider the free market argument and its best-case scenario for a bit.

- people push their children to go after what pays well
- a small proportion of those children do manage to get absorbed in the white collar workforce and rise up the economic ladder
- they're now earning well + build an appreciation for good products/infrastructure
- but as they're conditioned to believe blue-collar work is lower dignity, they now refuse to pay craftspersons their due

contrast this to a society with dignity of labour and no class bias and you will see this money from scalable white collar professions roll back to the unscalable service class. everyone benefits.

in the first case, even as some individuals manage to climb the economic ladder, they bring with them an internalized bias that prevents them from properly valuing and compensating the work done by the service class. 

whereas in a society that upholds the inherent dignity of all labor, the economic benefits get cycled back to support and elevate those providing essential services.

my point is how undervaluing blue-collar and service work leads to a self-perpetuating cycle of talent being diverted away from these critical roles. if these jobs are not respected and compensated appropriately, it discourages people from pursuing them, which then further degrades the quality and status of that work.

it's a compounding cycle.

https://t.co/qBCQCH4XUj

this is the second-order problem of not respecting your blue collar workforce. no one wants to be a good plumber if they can help it. and this outlook towards core infrastructure-building jobs is partly why we have poor infrastructure.

when you consider what you're trading off, the "it's a free market, go after more lucrative jobs" doesn't sound great.

money gives you the power to exercise your culture. 

to think that a specific group of people should only earn x and not a cent more is to implicitly assert that they should not have a right to exercise their culture; their culture is not worth exercising. 

classic victims of this bias are domestic workers and people in the service industry.

when you prescribe or accept that specific groups should only earn a certain fixed amount, regardless of the value they provide, you are secretly telling them that their cultural practices, needs and aspirations are less worthy.

the stated reasons may be quite different, but the implicit reasons are class snobbishness and cultural hegemony.

if you maintain a certain level of distance and objectivity during any experience, you'll quickly realise how much of it is just you convincing yourself of it; how much of it is just you buying the hype. you can easily see this by seeing that your before and after state is unchanged. you're not feeling any special or transformed at all. 

every such instance is a metaphorical slap into awareness.

the problem is you become invested in certain beliefs, emotions, or interpretations, and then struggle to see reality without those concepts clouding your judgment.

this is why traveling alone to places is a huge blackpill against travel itself. when you're in a group, you tend to buy the narrative and hype of the group and allow it to dictate your own judgments about the place.

but travel alone and you realize that the thing that most contributes to your well-being is your own self. that's the highest-order bit.

"i can't do shit alone" nibbas will never experience the joys of having the locus of your wellbeing within your own self.
